channel.name: IntelliJ IDEA EAP for minor updates

build.message:
A new IntelliJ IDEA 2018.2 EAP build is here:

  • Docker: New Context folder field in the Docker run configuration.
  • Docker: The Use Soft Wraps action that wraps words in docker logs.
  • File Watchers plugin: Ability to set a global file watcher.
For more details please refer to the blog post.

IntelliJ IDEA 2018.2.1 RC is now available!

  • Fixed the incorrect NPE warning in reversed indexed for loop: IDEA-195855.
For more details please refer to the release notes.

IntelliJ IDEA 2018.2.1 EAP is here with the several notable improvements:

  • Structure panel now shows correct data again: IDEA-183801.
  • New files are shown in Package view: IDEA-195578.
  • Gradle: the IDE doesn’t modify any wrapper-related files on project synchronization or import,
    when the Use gradle ‘wrapper’ task configuration option is selected: IDEA-116898.
  • Groovy 3.0 support enhancements.
For more details, please refer to the blog post.

IntelliJ IDEA 2018.2 RС2 is now available for download!

  • MacBook Touch bar: the Add configuration button in Run/Debug configuration dialog.
  • MacBook Touch bar: new Welcome dialog layout
    • .
  • MacBook Touch bar: small usability improvements in the debugger layout.
To learn more, read the blog post.

A new IntelliJ IDEA 2016.3.8 bug-fix update is here! The update brings an important fix to the built-in
SSH client and makes it compatible with the new GitHub cryptographic standards.

IntelliJ IDEA 15.0.6 is now available. For the list of fixes see the release notes.

IMPORTANT: The update also contains important security fixes and is strongly recommended for all users.
For more details please read this blog post.

Meet IntelliJ IDEA 2018.2, the second massive IntelliJ IDEA update of 2018!

  • Java
    • Java 11 support
    • The IDE now displays type hints for long method chains.
    • New preview panel for the Extract Method refactoring.
    • Many new Java inspections & intentions.
  • User Interface
    • MacBook Touch bar support.
  • Version Control Systems
    • Files with merge conflicts are now grouped under the new Merge Conflicts node
      on the Git Log tab.
    • Diff Preview Panel is now available in the VCS Log.
    • Tags can be deleted from Git commits via the context menu of the Log tab.
    • Multiple GitHub accounts can be configured in Preferences | Version Control | GitHub.
    • Several Log tabs can be opened in the Version Control Tool Window.
  • Spring Boot
    • New Spring Runtime Beans diagram to visualize the dependencies between beans in the runtime.
    • Ability to manage HTTP requests mappings from the Run Dashboard.
Visit the What's New page to discover all the new features in IntelliJ IDEA 2018.2

IntelliJ IDEA 2018.1.6 is released!

  • Fixed a throwable exception: unable to get stub builder: IDEA-181227.
  • Fixed the issue that caused the go to Class/File/Symbol pop-ups to leak
    via the native window and focus traversal policy: IDEA-192184.
  • Сorrected the treatment of a Spring @Nullable annotation: IDEA-182842.
For more details please refer to the blog post.

IntelliJ IDEA 2018.1.5 is here and it fixes several regressions:

  • The IDE doesn’t lose focus after using/canceling navigation pop-ups/menus:
    IDEA-191839.
  • Navigating to class (Сtrl+N /cmd+O) now works correctly again: IDEA-191860.
  • The compiling doesn’t fail for the projects that store .iml externally:
    IDEA-191328.
For more details please refer to the blog post.

The IntelliJ IDEA 2017.3.5 bug-fix update is now released!

  • The updated built-in SSH client is now compatible with the new GitHub cryptographic
    standards.
  • The Eclipse compiler bundled with IntelliJ IDEA now supports Java 9 sources:
    IDEA-184951.
  • The Change Signature dialog now uses the system-wide color scheme for the
    parameters list: IDEA-134545.
The JDK has been updated to 1.8.0_152-release-1024-b15, with the following fixes integrated:
  • Unlimited cryptographic policy is enabled by default: JRE-638.
  • The issue of empty Memory View in Debug session of application running with JRE 9
    was fixed: JRE-641.
For more details, please refer to the blog post.

A new IntelliJ IDEA 2017.2.7 bug-fix update is here! The update brings an important fix to the built-in
SSH client and makes it compatible with the new GitHub cryptographic standards.

IntelliJ IDEA 2017.2.6 is here!
This update contains following important fixes:

  • Diagrams: System crash when generating a database diagram IDEA-179756.
  • Cache corruption when using .GitIgnore plugin IDEA-180296
  • Java: Code inspection hangs in the latest 2017.2.5 release (IDEA-181519).
  • Gradle issue with Java 9: a Gradle NPE when a project was imported.
  • Command-line Diff between directories didn't work.
  • Spring Boot properties were not set properly when starting the application
  • Hide file extensions in editor tabs option wasn't working correctly.

For more details, please refer to the release notes.

A new IntelliJ IDEA 2017.1.6 bug-fix update is here! The update brings an important fix to the built-in
SSH client and makes it compatible with the new GitHub cryptographic standards.

A new IntelliJ IDEA 2017.1 bugfix update is out.

Among bugfixes, the update brings several important
performance fixes for editing JavaScript, opening
Terminal and project indexing.

A new IntelliJ IDEA 2016.3.8 bug-fix update is here! The update brings an important fix to the built-in

RubyMine 2018.2 released!

Here are the highlights:

  • Attach the debugger to remote processes. How-to
  • Significant code insight improvements
  • YAML code formatter [RUBY-2185]
  • Support for YAML anchors and aliases [RUBY-21454]
  • Support for JSON schema in YAML files [RUBY-20082]
  • Ability to copy key paths in YAML files [RUBY-7231]
  • chruby support [RUBY-14086]
  • asdf support [RUBY-20370]
  • Remote SDK configuration improvements
  • Ability to rerun failed tests [RUBY-1631]

Other improvements include new intention actions for Ruby and JavaScript, better CoffeeScript support, new Git actions, new icons, and MacBook Touch Bar support.

Visit the What's new page to learn more about the new features and download v2018.2.

See the release notes for the full list of improvements and please report any issues you encounter.

Meet PyCharm 2016.3, the third big PyCharm update of 2016!

Visit What's new in PyCharm 2016.3 to see a full overview of new features added in PyCharm 2016.3
and learn about the great progress PyCharm made in earlier 2016 releases.

Some highlights:

  • 40% faster debugger
  • Support for Python 3.5 and 3.6
  • Improved Python console: prototype in the console, and then copy your code into your project
  • Better VCS integration: we've worked hard on making VCS better, check out the details on jetbrains.com
  • And much more

If you decide to switch your old license, purchase a subscription at jetbrains.com as an existing customer and
get a 40% automatic discount before January 1, 2017.

Meet PyCharm 2016.3, the third big PyCharm update of 2016!

Visit What's new in PyCharm 2016.3 for a full list of new features and an overview video.

And here're the highlights:

  • Set up Django projects on Remote Interpreters: no more need to have an interpreter installed locally
  • Improved Python console: quickly check code, and then copy-paste it into your project with automatic formatting
  • Better Variable Explorer: see your own variables first
  • Full support for Python 3.6
  • Better and faster version control integration
  • Updated database tools

  • Lettuce scenario outlines

  • and more...

Latest versions of pip starting from v10.0 changed parts of their APIs. That’s why several older versions of PyCharm,including
the one you're using, became incompatible with the newer pip versions. If you want to use latest versions of pip, please update PyCharm.

PyCharm 2017.3 is out now!

Visit What's new in PyCharm 2017.3 for the full list of new features.

The highlights of this release:

  • It's faster. Indexing got faster for both Python and JavaScript code. Faster variable
    loading during debugging. Debugging is now fast by default on Windows and macOS
  • Scientific Mode. The scientific mode puts all the tools you need for analyzing data at
    your fingertips
  • Easier setup for virtualenvs. With PyCharm 2017.3 it is easy to set up virtualenvs
    when creating a project, and when configuring existing projects
  • New REST Client. If you develop an API, you often need to construct a request to test
    your software. PyCharm 2017.3 has an all-new REST client
  • And more

PyCharm 2018.1 is out now!

Visit What's new in PyCharm 2018.1 for the full list of new features.

The highlights of this release:

  • More data science. PyCharm now supports dividing your Python files into code cells,
    and gives you precise control over choosing which parts to run. The all-new scientific project type helps
    you get started faster.
  • Choose what to commit. If you like to keep your commits tidy, you will really
    appreciate the ability to choose not only which files to commit, but also which parts within those files
    to commit.
  • Connect to your code. PyCharm 2018.1 makes it easier than ever to connect to a remote
    Python interpreter using SSH. Whether you’re coding on a Raspberry Pi or an EC2 box, try it now!
  • Python 3.7. Even though Python 3.7 won’t be released until this summer, it’s already
    supported in PyCharm. If you haven’t yet, check out how dataclasses can make your code better.
  • And more

PyCharm 2018.2 Out Now

    and automatically creates a Pipenv for existing projects
  • Quick Documentation has been improved to make it easier to get the information you
    need inside the IDE
  • Both fixtures and BDD are now supported for pytest
  • The reStructuredText editor shows you a preview of the document you’re writing
  • And more

The new minor release of our professional PHP IDE with various improvements and bug fixes, is now available for download!

This release brings new bugfixes and usability improvements:

Meet WebStorm 2016.3, the third big WebStorm update of 2016!

Visit What’s new in WebStorm 2016.3 for a full list of new features and an overview video.

And here’re the highlights:

  • Support for Flow: type errors are reported right in the editor; Flow-powered code completion
  • Support for React Native: code completion; running and debugging apps in WebStorm
  • Better TypeScript support: more precise code completion and analysis; smarter Rename refactoring
    that understands the inheritance hierarchy
  • Set of inspections and quick-fixes for migrating the code to ES6 and a new Convert to class intention
  • Integration with Stylelint; support for PostCSS via a plugin; running and debugging tests with Protractor;
    quick bootstrap to run and debug Node.js app in Docker; better support for ES6 destructuring, and even more!

  • Auto imports now work better in projects that use lerna, yarn workspaces or TypeScript 3.0 project
    references (WEB-30212)
  • The bundled TypeScript version was update to 3.0 (WEB-34144)
  • "Surround selection on typing quote or brace" option is now on by default (WEB-33249)
  • Support for the Nullish Coalescing proposal in JavaScript (WEB-32660)

What's fixed:

  • JavaScript code completion now works fine in webpack configuration files (WEB-33420)
  • Changing the opening tag of the Vue component now updates the closing tag as well (WEB-33452)

Please note that this build requires an active subscription.

  • Support for Angular 6 and Angular CLI 6: new projects are now created properly from the
    IDE Welcome screen (WEB-32643), and you can add the new app blueprints (WEB-32557)
  • Code completion for the TSLint options has been updated (WEB-25633)

You can learn more about these improvements in the blog post.

WebStorm 2018.1.2 is now available!

What's new:

  • When renaming an Angular component, you can now automatically rename the
    related .ts, .html, and .css files (WEB-31644)
  • Auto import for the RxJS operators now respects the new import style introduced
    in RxJS 6.0 (WEB-32299)
  • With the new option in the JavaScript debug configuration, the breakpoints in the
    code that is executed on page load are hit on the first app run
  • The new option in the TypeScript code style settings allows omitting types in the
    generated JSDoc comments (WEB-28964)
  • More precise code completion for object properties after you explicitly check
    that they exist (WEB-31759)

What's fixed:

  • The log messages are again now shown in the Console tab of the npm, Gulp, and
    Grunt tool windows (WEB-32003)
  • The new React 16.3 lifecycle methods are now resolved and are available in code
    completion suggestions when @types/react is installed (WEB-32069)
  • Replace with the template string intention now works correctly for expressions
    with the ternary operator (WEB-24100)

You can learn more about these improvements in the blog post.

WebStorm 2018.1.1 is now available!

What's new:

  • Better support for Yarn workspaces: WebStorm now provides proper code completion for the dependencies
    listed in the workspace's package.json (WEB-29250)
  • Stylelint now works in the Vue single-file components (WEB-26391) and HTML files (WEB-23695)
  • In the JavaScript and TypeScript code style settings you can now configure whether to add file extensions in
    imports or not (WEB-31398)

What's fixed:

  • The code completion for methods and properties defined in the CommonJS modules has been improved
    (WEB-28158, WEB-26937, WEB-24161, WEB-22342)
  • The problem with editing of Pug files is now fixed (WEB-31990)

You can read more about these improvements in the blog post.

WebStorm 2018.1.1 is now available!

Explore the new features and download WebStorm 2018.1 on our website.

Here are the key highlights in WebStorm 2018.1:

  • Format your code with Prettier with a shortcut, Alt-Shift-Cmd/Ctrl-P.
  • Commit to Git or add to a changelist only selected changes from a file.
  • Enjoy the new, more compact and lightweight documentation popup for
    JavaScript, TypeScript, and other languages.
  • Create new Vue projects from the IDE's Welcome screen using Vue CLI,
    and create new components using the Extract Vue Component refactoring.
  • Configure Yarn or npm as a package manager used in the project, in the
    Node.js and npm preferences.
  • Debug React Native apps that use Expo, as well as those already built and
    launched on a device.

You can read more about the WebStorm 2018.1.1 bug-fix update in this blog post.

Here are the key highlights of WebStorm 2017.3 that you can’t miss:

  • Enjoy improved code completion and documentation for standard JavaScript

CLion 2018.2 is now available!

Explore the new features and download CLion 2018.2 on our website.

CLion is becoming a more mature C/C++ IDE. See for yourself by trying the following new features and improvements in the 2018.2 update:

  • An experimental clangd-based C++ language engine complements CLion's own C++ language engine (on by default on Linux and macOS),
    helping to highlight code errors and warnings in the editor.
  • A new inspection detects situations when arguments of the same type are passed to a function in the wrong order.
  • Gradle C++ and Compilation Database projects support. Full code insight is provided for both.
  • Ability to recompile a single file (for CMake and compilation database formats) without triggering the full project recompilation.
  • Support for Google Sanitizers.
  • IDE performance improvements.

Rider 2018.2 EAP build 5 (182.3894.140):

Roslyn Analyzers
  • We’ve introduced initial support for .ruleset files. Enable it by going to File | Settings | Editor | Inspection Settings
    and selecting the check-box Read settings from editorconfig and project settings.
  • Settings from stylecop.json are no longer ignored.
  • Roslyn Analyzers works again on .NET Core projects from newer SDKs, but still needs the non-Core MSBuild toolset
    to be run.
Unity support
  • Rider will only install the Unity Editor plugin into your project after it changes, rather than every time you open
    the project in Rider.
  • When you rename a serialized field, you’ll be asked to confirm before adding a FormerlySerializedAs attribute.
  • If you open a Unity project with Open Folder, an appropriate notification will be shown.

Changes inherited from ReSharper: see the ReSharper EAP page for more details.
Rider 2018.1.3 is here with a hotfix for the Zip Slip vulnerability.

Go to the next level with GoLand 2018.2:

  • Support for Go modules(vgo).

  • An enhanced Move refactoring.

  • New quick-fixes:Convert to expected type and Implement missing methods.

  • New Postfix Completion templates: .sort and .rr.

  • New Intention Actions: Add dot import alias, Remove dot import alias, and Introduce local variable.

  • Code Style: a new option called Add leading space to comment for disabling leading spaces
    for annotations that start with certain prefixes.

  • The debugger supports non-suspending breakpoints and lazy-loading for arrays, maps, and slices.

  • File watchers stores the configured File Watchers in the IDE settings and allows you to share them
    among different projects using the Project and Global options.

  • VCS updates: a new Merge Conflicts node groups files with merge conflicts for each changelist;
    the Log tab adds many improvements; a new option to skip the Push dialog for Git;
    and multiple GitHub accounts are supported.

  • User Interface: Touch Bar is supported, and you can now switch to dark window headers if you like.

To learn about the changes in more detail, read the announcement in our blog.

GoLand 2018.1.5 is out. This update mostly consists of bugfixes for UI and some Performance improvements.

GoLand 2018.1.4 is out. This update contains bugfixes for Move refactoring and Code coverage,

GoLand 2018.1.3 is here! This update comes with lots of bug fixes and
improvements related to the UI and JavaScript and SQL support:

  • For side-effects import statement in JavaScript, code completion
    now includes non-JavaScript files as well, e.g. CSS.
  • GoLand now displays the type inferred by Flow server as a part
    of Brief Info that pops up when hovering an expression holding
    Ctrl or Cmd
  • Angular 6 improvements along with integration with Angular
    CLI 6 blueprints
  • TypeScript code completion updated according to the TSLint rules
  • Flow support within Vue files
  • Find Usages on SQL files now includes the DDL Data Sources that
    use them
  • Support for .sqlite/.sqlite3 files
  • Run SQL Script action now available in the Database and Project
    tool windows. This action can be used to import data from SQL
    dump files.
  • Fixed Z-order of child windows that was broken in one of the earlier
    builds is broken no more.

GoLand 2018.1.2 is out! Here's a list of what you'll find inside:

  • The Test Runner now supports ANSI escape codes and colors
    the output accordingly.
  • The Dep integration had been optimized in terms of when it runs
    dep status.
  • Two new Postfix Completion templates generating code that
    checks if an error variable is not nil: rre and rrv.
  • The Search for text occurrences check-box, which is offered
    when calling Find Usages, now keeps the state.
  • The Join Lines action now works correctly (previously was broken
    on comments).
  • The Rename refactoring on an Angular component, will prompt
    you to also rename the related .ts, .html, and .css files.
  • For JavaScript object properties, when you explicitly check that
    they exist, you will now get more accurate code completion.
  • Better VCS Log performance when scrolling.
  • And some other improvements…

To learn more and also see the screenshots, read the blog post.

GoLand 2018.1.1 is out, with important debugger bugfixes:

  • Fixed broken debugger because of a recent macOS
    command line tools update (GO-5527)
  • Variables declared in if/for/switch statements are

  • Breakpoints can now be unset when running several
    debugging sessions

Woo-hoo, GoLand 2018.1 is out! The update brings even smarter coding
assistance, even richer built-in integrations, and numerous other improvements.
GoLand 2018.1 revises the support for Go, JavaScript and TypeScript, improves
the debugger, Git support, and many other parts of the IDE.

To learn about the changes in more detail, read the announcement in our blog.

GoLand 2017.3.4 is out. This update addresses the issue of the idle debugger which
was not working because of a recent macOS command line tools update (GO-5527).
GoLand 2017.3.3 is here with working SSH GitHub access and other important bugfixes.

GoLand 2017.3.2 is here. Among other things, the update addresses
a couple of issues related to Code Formatting and Run Configurations.

GoLand 2017.3.1 is out. This minor update fixes many bugs, increases stability
and improves performance. Most notable changes include:

  • Code Style settings offer syntax highlighting options for function calls.
  • The IDE bundles the Monokai color scheme.
  • The Fill struct intention action adds missing keys to the partially
    initialized structs.
  • Fixed an annoying bug related to the cross-platform compilation (GO-2683).
  • The Debugger updated to the latest version of Delve and now better supports
    macOS as well as Go 1.10.
  • Lots of other bugfixes related to the Go functionality (QuickDoc,
    Inspections, Test Runner, and Refactorings) as well as to the platform.

At last, it’s here! GoLand 2017.3, the new Go IDE from JetBrains,
is available for download and purchase!

Read about GoLand's functionality, licensing model and further
updates in the announcement.

A fresh GoLand 2018.2 EAP build is out!

It contains various bugfixes, see the release note for more details.
